newsitem.title: FINLAND: Helsinki stocks firm, strength holds in Merita.
newsitem.headline: Helsinki stocks firm, strength holds in Merita.

text.p: Shares ended another solid session ahead after a hesitant start on Tuesday, the pace mounting during the day as Merita continued to rally, Nokia rose and there was renewed interest in forestries, brokers said.

The HEX index ended up 0.5 percent at 2,265.49 after again grazing year-high levels, with total volume a solid 480 million markka, quite well spread but boosted by an in-house transfer. Nokia was calm, ending up 1.40 markka at 216.00.
"We've had some domestic and foreign clients seeing a number of shares are now again attractively priced," one broker said.
In his view this did not refer to recently strong Merita, but other brokers saw more upside in the bank: "It will go and see what 15.00 markka feels like, then we'll see," said one.
Another agreed, but said at around 15-16 markka Merita's appeal may be dampened by the weight of its property portfolio.
Finnish property markets remain in the doldrums despite a marked economic recovery from the depths of the early 1990s.
Forestries were boosted by encouraging profits from Canadian and U.S. paper companies, although many brokers were still bearish on the outlook for Finnish forestries next year.
"If U.S. growth falls short of expectations, there may be extra supply from there to Europe," said one.

Enso ended up 0.30 markka at 35.70 after its January-August results came in line with expectations, but failed to raise much interest. Metsa-Serla was the liveliest with over 50 million markka volume, picking up 0.10 markka to close at 33.00.
Elsewhere, Huhtamaki continued to ease in fairly solid trade amid profit-taking after it surged on Friday's news of an asset-swap with Hershey.

Raision Tehtaat picked up sharp gains but in relatively thin volume after it said it would buy a leading Swedish margarine maker, which also gave it a marketing channel for its cholesterol reducing margarine.
"Investors really liked this," one broker said.
Total volume was boosted by Kesko's internal transfer of a 26 percent holding in Merita controlled real-estate firm Citycon from its recently acquired Tuko subsidiary.
